results.title: [Fred Daley Collection]
results.material_description: 8mm home movie reels (small and large). Most already digitised.
results.brief_description:
A collection of silent, 8mm home movies by steam train enthusiast Fred Daley, capturing scenes of steam trains, the Daley family, vintage cars, railway stations, and snapshots of rural and city life.

The films are mainly shot on family holidays in various locations across Victoria from the City of Melbourne to Warburton, Apollo Bay and Mornington Peninsula, to a long road trip to Cooma, New South Wales. There is also a work specially dedicated to Victoria’s most famous steam train, Puffing Billy.

Fred was a skilled filmmaker - we are presented with polished films, employing use of a tripod, nifty title sequences and astute editing. Whilst filming steam trains was his passion, made evident by the many hours of footage dedicated to them, Fred also shows the family’s love of the outdoors on summer holidays, road trips, gardens, Luna Park, a game of football at the MCG, picnics and relaxing on the beach.

The titles shown here were made from the mid-to-late 1960s but Fred’s collection spans some fifty years. Kindly donated to the ACMI Collection by Fred’s son Neville, Fred’s Films provide memories not only for his family but also for the collective memory of Victorians, steam train buffs, filmmakers, historians, or anyone who has the pleasure of watching them.

A collection of silent home movies filmed by train enthusiast Fred Daley.
Footage of:
Daley Family
Steam trains
Vintage cars
Railway stations
Family holidays
Locations across Victoria
Warburton
Echuca
Heathcote
Mornington
Tasmania
Alice Springs

results.title: Fred's Films. [Luna Park] [excerpt]
results.brief_description: Filmed in the mid 1960s by steam train enthusiast and home movie maker Fred Daley who captures a family outing to the popular sea-side amusement park in St Kilda. ‘Luna Park’ is shown in all its summertime glory with the ‘River Boats’, the ‘Dodgems’, the ‘Rotor’ (a washing spin cycle for humans!), ‘The Spinner’ and of course its famous wooden roller coasters, the ‘Big Dipper’ and the ‘Scenic Railway’. Courageous Fred even films during the ride where you catch a glimpse of Port Phillip Bay from the very top!

results.title: For Better - For Worse
results.creator_credit: John M. Bale, Don Anderson and Tasmanian Film Corporation
results.brief_description: Dramatization of common misconceptions surrounding marriage and the types of stress contributing to marriage breakdown. Refers to alcohol, the consequences of “mateship” and violence.

results.title: Gel
results.creator_credit: Ralph Henderson, Eric White and Films Sagittaire
results.brief_description: Produced for the Davis Gelatine company, the film uses a domestic science student to outline some of the properties and uses of gelatine. Various examples of modern gelatine cookery are also shown.

results.title: Fabric of a Dream: the Fletcher Jones Story
results.creator_credit: Dennis K. Smith, Neil Angwin, Melanie Coombs, SBS Independent, Melodrama Pictures and Film Australia
results.brief_description:
An inspiring man with bold and imaginative ideas, Fletcher Jones was influenced by Japanese reformer Toyohiko Kagawa, one of the most remarkable social activists of his time. Jones established his clothing design, retail and manufacturing business with an emphasis on quality, service and innovation. However, his primary concern was for people - both his customers and his workers - and they, in turn, were intensely loyal. This is a celebration of the man and his dream - of a model working environment based on values other than simple profit - set against the backdrop of 20th Century history.
[Source: NFSA Film Australia Collection National Interest Program]

results.title: Unfolding Florence: the many lives of Florence Broadhurst
results.creator_credit: Katherine Thomson, Gillian Armstrong, Charles Hannah, Sue Clothier, SBS Independent, New South Wales Film and Television Office, Becker Entertainment and Film Australia
results.brief_description: Almost everyone thinks they know who I was and, of course, everyone thinks they know who killed me. A celebration of the life of flamboyant Australian design pioneer Florence Broadhurst, this highly original documentary explores the many lives of one larger-than-life woman. Acclaimed director Gillian Armstrong “unfolds” Broadhurst’s story from her birth, in 1899, into a farming family in outback Australia, to 1920s Shanghai, where she ran her own performing arts academy, to the fashion scene of 1930s London, and to her painting tours of northern and central Australia in the early 1950s. In her last incarnation, as a designer and manufacturer of wallpapers, Broadhurst produced high-quality, handcrafted wallpapers in luxurious, oversized patterns with vivid combinations of colours, inspired by an eclectic range of sources. More than 100 years after her birth, her work has been rediscovered by the world’s leading fashion, interior and homeware designers and her prints are in huge demand internationally. Broadhurst was brutally murdered on 15 October 1977 at her Paddington premises; and the killer has never been identified. Broadhurst was renowned for her flamboyant clothes, antique jewellery and coiffed, hennaed hair. “Unfolding Florence” explores her life in a vibrant and unconventional style, with more than a touch of humour and irreverence; a fitting approach to this unusual woman’s story. Cast includes Judi Farr (as Florence) and Felicity Price (as the young Florence).
results.title_for_label: Unfolding Florence: the many lives of Florence Broadhurst
results.creator_credit_for_label: Katherine Thomson, Gillian Armstrong, Charles Hannah, Sue Clothier, SBS Independent, New South Wales Film and Television Office, Becker Entertainment and Film Australia

results.title: Rosalie Kunoth-Monks
results.brief_description:
Episode of Series “Australian biography”.
Rosalie Kunoth-Monks: Aboriginal activist, actor, social worker, Parliamentary Candidate 1979-1981, President Aboriginal Legal Aid NT 1983-87, 1990-93, was born in Utopia, Central Australia, 1937 and is of German Aboriginal parentage. Kunoth-Monks discusses her education at St Mary’s Children’s Hostel, Alice Springs, and on being discovered by Charles and Elsa Chauvel as the lead in “Jedda”. She talks about working on the film, and her family’s response to it, in particular the sexual references. A greater passion was to help people, and Rosalie joined the Community of the Holy Name in Melbourne and was a nun for ten years, also gaining training during this period in childcare. Working as an Aboriginal liaison officer in Victoria after leaving the sisterhood, Kunoth-Monks also established the first Aboriginal Family Group home, in addition to marrying during this period. A return to Central Australia saw her working for the Country Liberal Party and being active in social welfare before she returned, full circle, to Utopia.

results.title: Sugar Slaves
results.creator_credit: Jean Jacques Portail, Trevor Graham, Penny Robins, Australian Broadcasting Corporation, Arcadia Films, Annamax Media and Film Australia
results.brief_description: In 1994 Australia took over Cuba to become the largest exporter of raw sugar in the world. Ironically in that same year, Australian Islanders descendants from the South Pacific Islanders who were kidnapped and enticed by white slave-traders and transported to Queensland to work the Queensland sugar plantations over one hundred years ago, finally won official recognition as a distinct ethnic community - the only substantial black migrant group in Australia. This documentary film tells of the hardships, the appalling working conditions and the exploitation which took place in Queensland between 1863 and 1904 of about 60,000 “Kanakas”, mainly men, but some women, slave labourers from the South Pacific Islands, including Vanuatu and the Solomon Islands. It follows several Australian Islander descendants as they try to retrace the history of their long-lost relatives and combines their personal stories with archival footage, stills, newsreels and quotes from newspaper articles of the time. Many Australians are unaware of our not so proud past dealings in human trafficking and slave labour and the term “blackbirding” (white slave-traders’ term for sailing in and stealing the Islanders) and so “Sugar slaves” for that very reason makes compelling viewing. Contains some b&w sequences. Narrated by Jonathan Holmes.

results.title: Wine service: a guide for professional waiters
results.creator_credit: Australian Wine and Brandy Corporation, John Kingsford-Smith and Kingcroft Productions
results.brief_description: Produced by the Australian Wine Board, this work features the skills and knowledge required for wine waiting. A short instructional film, it aims to assist in making the right selection of wine varieties to match with food, relying on the knowledge of the restaurant staff. Get the insider knowledge from inside the waiters’ pantry: “it’s important you have a sound knowledge of your foods, and more particularly of your wines”.
